message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy is reserved for severe depression that is unresponsive to other treatments or when there is an urgent need for a rapid response. It would be inappropriate as a first-line treatment. Psychotherapy and medication (such as citalopram or sertraline) are first-line treatments for depression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy is typically reserved for severe cases of depression that do not respond to other treatments, and would not be an appropriate first-line treatment. Psychotherapy and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as citalopram and sertraline are commonly used first-line treatments for depression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy is typically reserved for cases of severe depression that are resistant to other treatments or for patients at high risk of suicide. It is not appropriate as a first-line treatment for this patient's symptoms. Psychotherapy, SSRIs such as citalopram and sertraline are all appropriate first-line treatments for depression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy is generally reserved for severe or treatment-resistant cases and would not be a first-line treatment option. Psychotherapy and SSRIs such as Citalopram and Sertraline are first-line options for patients with symptoms of depression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is generally reserved for cases where other treatments have failed, and is not recommended as a first-line treatment. Psychotherapy, antidepressants such as Citalopram and Sertraline are all appropriate first-line treatments for depression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is generally reserved for treatment-resistant cases of major depression, and not typically used as a first-line treatment. Psychotherapy and medication (such as Citalopram and Sertraline) are more commonly used as initial treatments for depression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy is generally not considered a first-line treatment for depression, especially in a patient without severe symptoms such as suicidal thoughts or psychosis. Psychotherapy and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as Citalopram and Sertraline are more commonly used as first-line treatments for depression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy is typically reserved for severe, treatment-resistant depression and is not appropriate as a first-line treatment option. Psychotherapy, Citalopram and Sertraline are all appropriate first-line treatment options for depression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is reserved for severe cases of depression that haven’t responded to other treatments, and the patient’s symptoms don’t indicate that level of severity yet. Psychotherapy and medication are first-line treatments for depression, with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as citalopram and sertraline commonly prescribed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is a very effective and safe treatment option for severe depression, but it is usually reserved for cases where other treatments have failed or are not appropriate. It would not be appropriate as a first-line treatment for this patient. Psychotherapy, citalopram, and sertraline are all reasonable first-line treatment options for depression.
